2867a97f-3f55-4116-94c0-a4426eb3d700.description: Professional Development Day is a day-long event comprised of a keynote address and various break-out sessions. This year's keynote speaker was Dr. Mark Milliron. Through breakout sessions this earner is able to better understand fiscal planning, leadership, personal well-being, professional skill development, managing change and changes in higher education, and utilizing technology to engage students.
2867a97f-3f55-4116-94c0-a4426eb3d700.name: Professional Development Day Fall 2020

badge_template_activities.title: Attend the all-day event.

Through breakout sessions this earner is able to better understand fiscal planning, leadership, personal wellbeing, professional skill development, managing change and changes in higher education, and utilizing technology to engage students.
701875e5-3b03-4f36-856f-6724d3af3aa4.name: Professional Development Day 2019

05c7c8f9-83d8-4d8b-9330-6bdd798aa492.description: The Center for Professional Excellence's Presenter badge is awarded to those who present or facilitate sessions in the CPE. By presenting a session to colleagues, participants show they are committed to not only their own professional development but also to their colleagues'.

f2590667-3b28-48e9-aa50-09efca0aa9f0.description: Dean Dyer provided attendees with an introduction to Ally and how to use it in coursework. Ally is Blackboard’s tool to help you make your course content accessible. This hands on workshop will introduce Ally, show how to run the instructor report for courses, and understand and fix common mistakes (such as missing headings, mixing text and image descriptions, contrast issues, etc). Come work on your courses in a group setting.
f2590667-3b28-48e9-aa50-09efca0aa9f0.name: CPE - Workshop Wednesday - Ally

6f2ab9b5-8cff-4312-b317-ddbc9d9d4dbf.description: Individuals who attended this event were provided with an introduction to C4S progress surveys. Please join Kim O’Brien as she illustrates how C4S Progress Surveys can be an efficient and concise way to raise “Flags” and “Kudos” on students during critical points of the semester. During this session she will review the upcoming week 3 Progress Survey for Financial Aid attendance reporting, as well as how to give students a “nudge” in the right direction!
6f2ab9b5-8cff-4312-b317-ddbc9d9d4dbf.name: CPE - Workshop Wednesday - Connect4Success - Progress Surveys

1b1075aa-7b81-442f-b081-a5c695148bba.description: The New Faculty and Staff series is designed to welcome new hires to the campus and introduce them to the culture of Jefferson using the FISH! Philosophy. FISH! relies on four basic principles - Be There, Play, Make Their Day, and Choose Your Attitude. At this session, the New Faculty/Staff Series did a “Get to know our campus Scavenger Hunt”. Employees new to campus had to seek out help and information to complete the challenge.
1b1075aa-7b81-442f-b081-a5c695148bba.name: New Faculty and Staff Series - Campus Scavenger Hunt

5a6d021d-3b76-4310-822b-98950bb210b2.description: The student code of conduct is designed to ensure fair and impartial treatment of any person(s) accused of a violating of a rule, regulation or policy of the college through due process and procedure conducted with fairness to all. This seminar, led by Dr. Corey Campbell, will be an opportunity to discuss the existing code, discover proposed changes to the code and learn how your role correlates with the code.
5a6d021d-3b76-4310-822b-98950bb210b2.name: Student Code of Conduct Session

0f5dfea4-df3d-4cee-9b7e-71ca7fb6e0ad.description: Please join Dawn Bartlett as she plans on discussing the importance of maintaining a healthy balance in our work lives and home lives. fa1f7c02-46cc-44c0-8897-e84f720bbafe.description: Individuals who attended this event were provided with an introduction to scheduling advising appointments through C4S. Are you taking advantage of Connect4Success (C4S) to schedule appointments with your advisees? Join Heather O’Brien to learn how to do this and the advantages they have found using C4S for advising appointments. There will be time during the session to set this up in your C4S Calendar.
fa1f7c02-46cc-44c0-8897-e84f720bbafe.name: CPE - Workshop Wednesday - Connect4Success - Advising

238c2343-cf5f-404e-9a1d-f2a9d6a647d0.description: Ally is the new system Jefferson is using to help us improve the accessibility of our online resources for students with disabilities. This brief introduction will explain what ALLY does and show us how to generate an ALLY report for our class Blackboard sites. Following the introduction to ALLY, John Thomas will discuss library resources available for faculty and students and give us an overview of the use of the new library search system, PRIMO, that replaced our old system over the summer.
238c2343-cf5f-404e-9a1d-f2a9d6a647d0.name: Adjunct Series: ALLY and Library Services

badge_template_activities.title: This badge shows that participants have attended the Ally and Primo workshop at the Center for Professional Excellence. By attending this event, recipients have demonstrated an interest in professional development.

66f05eb0-6c4a-4a36-96de-f9de5d17b0ad.description: Anita Verma, a long-time yoga practitioner, will lead us in some simple and very adaptable poses that can help combat stiffness and fatigue that comes from sitting at our desks and standing in front of classrooms all day. Come join us and enjoy a refreshing break in your day!
66f05eb0-6c4a-4a36-96de-f9de5d17b0ad.name: Adjunct Series: Office Yoga

badge_template_activities.title: This badge shows that participants have attended the Office Yoga workshop at the Center for Professional Excellence. By attending this event, recipients have demonstrated an interest in professional development.

ab142f1a-190a-43e9-b4f9-a6c2fe403486.description: The Agribusiness and Hospitality Micro-Credential will provide producer training on entrepreneurship, marketing, sanitation and safety and food and beverage management. The goal of the microcredential is to increase producers knowledge and product availability to the local community. Students will earn 10 college credits that may be transferred to a certificate or degree program. These courses are a perfect fit for JCC's Hospitality & Tourism AAS or Applied Business Studies AOS degree programs.
ab142f1a-190a-43e9-b4f9-a6c2fe403486.name: Agribusiness and Hospitality Microcredential (Value Added Food Processing)

badge_template_activities.title: BUS 124, Marketing - 3 credits. This course is an introduction to marketing principles and functions designed to satisfy an organization's target markets by offering an appropriate marketing mix consisting of product, price, place, and promotion. The course is taught from an integrated marketing communications point of view with emphasis on the formulation of competitive strategies, market analysis, marketing information, and sales forecasting.

CUL 130, Sanitation & Safety - 1 credit. CUL 130 - Sanitation and Safety The course examines the proper sanitation and safety methods in the food service industry. Emphasis will be placed on problems, procedures, techniques, and practices in sanitation and safety. This course includes the exam for a sanitation certificate, accredited by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) -Conference for Food Protection (CFP).

BUS 240, Food & Beverage Management - 3 credits. This course provides a basic understanding of the principles of food and beverage production and service management. The course covers effective layout and design, sanitation and safety, menu planning, the purchasing cycle, and cost control procedures for both products and payroll.

BUS 150, Intro to Entrepreneurship - 3 credits. This course provides an introduction to the concept of entrepreneurship for students who may someday start or operate their own business. Topics include exploring the idea of becoming an entrepreneur, developing a successful business idea, moving from an idea to an entrepreneurial venture, and managing and growing the entrepreneurial firm.

3165d3a1-cd93-40c7-a196-c11013c58e2d.description: The microcredential in Business Leadership will enable learners to demonstrate competency in various aspects of business that are essential to successful leadership including marketing, management, entrepreneurship, accounting, and communications. This microcredential offers flexibility in course options, allowing students to customize course selection to their individual goals. Students will complete 9-10 credits (BUS 112 and two of the four other classes listed below).
3165d3a1-cd93-40c7-a196-c11013c58e2d.name: Business Leadership Microcredential

badge_template_activities.title: Mandatory: BUS 112, Intro to Business - 3 credits. This course provides an overview of the business world in contemporary society. Topics include the economic environment of business, ethics and social responsibility, securities and investments, types of business organization, entrepreneurship, and the functions of production, marketing, finance and accounting, business law, and management.

BUS 124, Marketing - 3 credits. This course is an introduction to marketing principles and functions designed to satisfy an organization's target markets by offering an appropriate marketing mix consisting of product, price, place, and promotion. The course is taught from an integrated marketing communications point of view with emphasis on the formulation of competitive strategies, market analysis, marketing information, and sales forecasting.

BUS 150, Intro to Entrepreneurship - 3 credits. This course provides an introduction to the concept of entrepreneurship for students who may someday start or operate their own business. Topics include exploring the idea of becoming an entrepreneur, developing a successful business idea, moving from an idea to an entrepreneurial venture, and managing and growing the entrepreneurial firm.

ACC 101, Accounting Principles - 4 credits. Designed to give the accounting & non-accounting major an understanding of basic accounting principles & practices as they apply to a sole proprietorship. Emphasis will be placed on; the theory of debits & credits; the accounting cycle; merchandise & service operations; prepaid expenses; unearned revenues & accruals; accounting systems; internal controls; cash; receivables; trading securities; inventory valuation & ethics in the accounting profession.

STA 151, Public Speaking - 3 credits. This course introduces extemporaneous speaking with emphasis on informative and persuasive speech. Students will prepare, present, and evaluate various types of speech. Attention will be given to communication theory, audience analysis, and the speechmaking process (research, organization, and delivery).

ecd8fc72-477d-407e-9d8f-eee76644ca62.description: SNEAK IN SOME YOGA! Yoga at your desk is perfect for anybody who spends much time working at a computer or in a cubicle. The sequence you will experience during this session is ideal for those who want to sneak in a quick yoga break or for those who are in healing and want to practice a little bit of opening with the support of a chair. Practice a little energetic hygiene and deep breathing! Open your heart, your shoulders and relieve tension!
ecd8fc72-477d-407e-9d8f-eee76644ca62.name: CPE - Workshop Wednesday - Desk Yoga

badge_template_activities.title: This badge shows that participants have attended the Desk Yoga Workshop Wednesday at the Center for Professional Excellence. By attending this event, recipients have demonstrated an interest in professional development.  On Wednesdays throughout the academic year, sessions will be held on a topic - first a brief presentation on the topic followed by an activity on the topic to help the participants gain a better understanding and receive one-on-one instruction.

6525b137-6486-4a5d-a26e-8ee9c5660d7f.description: Want to make advising time less hectic? Come with your list of advisees and walk away with a plan for your advisee meetings. The workshop coach for this session will be Heather O'Brien.
6525b137-6486-4a5d-a26e-8ee9c5660d7f.name: CPE - Workshop Wednesday - Plan for Advising

badge_template_activities.title: This badge shows that participants have attended the Plan for Advising Workshop Wednesday at the Center for Professional Excellence. By attending this event, recipients have demonstrated an interest in professional development.  On Wednesdays throughout the academic year, sessions will be held on a topic - first a brief presentation on the topic followed by an activity on the topic to help the participants gain a better understanding and receive one-on-one instruction.

68be54cc-b15d-4db1-b500-e8230318ace3.description: The microcredential in Direct Support Professional 1 will enable students to demonstrate competency in several key areas including understanding human services organization structures and functions, ethical behavior in the workplace, the importance of interpersonal communication skills, and first aid and CPR personal safety measures. Students will earn 13 college credit hours that may later be transferred to JCC's certificate or degree programs like Human Services AS.
68be54cc-b15d-4db1-b500-e8230318ace3.name: Direct Support Professional 1 Microcredential

badge_template_activities.title: HCM 101, Intro to Health Care Management - 3 credits. This course provides students with an overview of how health care institutions are organized and governed, the role of the management staff, physicians, nurses and other clinical support staff in these organizations, and the management systems designed for their efficient and effective operation.

HUS 101, Intro to Human Services - 3 credits. This course will focus on the history, scope and current status of the helping professions. The students will explore the impact of personal/cultural values, technical vocabulary and techniques used in human services delivery systems. This course introduces students to cultural competency and the skills needed to understand, communicate with and effectively interact with people across diverse cultures.

HUS 210, Professional Codes of Conduct - 3 credits. Designed to help students develop a framework for ethical behavior & to become more effective in addressing ethical issues in the field of Human Service, Chemical Dependency & Criminal Justice Programs. NASW, ACA, American Association of Marriage and Family Therapists, NAHSE, CASAC Cannon of Ethics and American Psychological Association standards will be used to build a theoretical framework for approaching ethical dilemmas.

STA 161, Interpersonal Communication - 3 credits. This course is designed to enable students to better understand interpersonal communication situations and improve the way they approach and respond to them. Types of human communication and interaction are emphasized, identified, defined, and analyzed. This course is intended to promote understanding of communication theory, rather than to develop performance skills.

HEA 102, Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) - 1 credit. Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (including, infants, children, adults) is designed to acquaint students with vital lifesaving information and skills in order to perform CPR/AED, rescue breathing, and emergency first aid.

86cad3cb-a085-4299-8ad6-d6d85226488e.description: This microcredential will enable students to demonstrate competency in various aspects of public speaking & interpersonal communication, specifically in terms of understanding communication styles and developing effective communication skills to lead employees, customers, students or shareholders and investors. Students will earn 9 college credits that may be transferred to a certificate or degree programs like JCC's Liberal Arts & Sciences: Humanities & Social Sciences degree programs.
86cad3cb-a085-4299-8ad6-d6d85226488e.name: Fundamentals of Effective Communication Microcredential

badge_template_activities.title: STA 151, Public Speaking - 3 credits. This course introduces extemporaneous speaking with emphasis on informative and persuasive speech. Students will prepare, present, and evaluate various types of speech. Attention will be given to communication theory, audience analysis, and the speechmaking process (research, organization, and delivery).

STA 161, Interpersonal Communications - 3 credits. This course is designed to enable students to better understand interpersonal communication situations and improve the way they approach and respond to them. Types of human communication and interaction are emphasized, identified, defined, and analyzed. This course is intended to promote understanding of communication theory, rather than to develop performance skills.

STA 211, Managing Conflict - 3 credits. This course is an initiation to the study of conflict management and resolution, designed to familiarize students with theory of conflict as well as a wide range of problem/solving techniques for practical application. Topics include the role of power, goals, perception, listening, negotiation, compromise, mediation, and communication skills in conflict.

f730ed1d-86ac-48af-a186-85c5c04a68bc.description: This microcredential will enable students to demonstrate competency in various aspects of healthcare office management, with a focus on accounting and finance in the health care industry. Health Care Management 1 microcredential is not a pre-requisite for this. Students will earn ten college credit hours that may later be transferred to one of Jefferson's certificate or degree programs. Healthcare Management 2 courses are a perfect fit for JCC's Health Care Management AS degree program.
f730ed1d-86ac-48af-a186-85c5c04a68bc.name: Healthcare Management II Microcredential

badge_template_activities.title: HCM 110, Intro to the US Health Care System - 3 credits. This course explores the US Health Care System. Focuses include historical development, current configuration & possible future directions. Includes study of health system development, key influencers, accessibility, financing, changing components & the effects of the system on patients, providers, government, insurers & society.

ACC 101, Accounting Principles - 4 credits. This course is designed to give an understanding of basic accounting principles and practices as they apply to the sole proprietorship. Special emphasis will be placed on: the theory of debits and credits; the accounting cycle; merchandise and service operations; prepaid expenses; unearned revenues and accruals; accounting systems; internal controls; cash; receivables; trading securities; inventory valuation and ethics in the accounting profession.

HCM 220, Healthcare Financing - 3 credits. This course addresses the systems and uses of accounting and financial planning in health care including planning and control of cost factors in the health care industry. This course provides a conceptual and practical knowledge of health care finance, which includes all sources of funding the various programs, third party payers, managed care contracts, and valuations that have an impact on the health care organization.

ce3c3ff7-368c-4f50-a209-287c791dca7e.description: The microcredential in Health Care Management 1 will enable students to demonstrate competency in various aspects of healthcare office management including medical terminology, spreadsheet applications and introduction to health care management. Students will earn nine college credit hours that may later be transferred to one of Jefferson's certificate or degree programs. Health Care Management 1 course requirements are a perfect fit for JCC's Health Care Management AS degree program.
ce3c3ff7-368c-4f50-a209-287c791dca7e.name: Healthcare Management I Microcredential

badge_template_activities.title: OFC 245, Medical Terminology - 3 credits. This course is designed to teach the language of medicine to those who have elected a career in a medically-related profession. The study will include the basic structure of medical words including prefixes, suffixes, roots, combining forms, and plurals. Emphasis will be on building and understanding the professional vocabulary necessary for office employment in a medically-related field.

BUS 160, Spreadsheet Applications - 3 credits. Provides in-depth intro to a spreadsheet program. Topics include formulas, functions, charting, formatting worksheets, absolute cell references, working w/large datasets, what-if analysis, financial functions, data tables, amortization schedules, cell protection, worksheet database manipulation, lookup functions, database functions, templates, working w/multiple worksheets & workbooks, PivotTables, PivotCharts & additional spreadsheet capabilities.

HCM 101, Intro to Health Care Management - 3 credits. This course provides students with an overview of how health care institutions are organized and governed, the role of the management staff, physicians, nurses and other clinical support staff in these organizations, and the management systems designed for their efficient and effective operation.

005d95b1-bb37-4b23-b172-4b098e1e0a25.description: The Hospitality microcredential will provide those looking to start their career with the background to work in a customer-focused industry, while learning necessary skills such as basic hospitality, customer service, sanitation & safety, & beverage management. Students will earn 10 college credits that may later be transferred to one of Jefferson's certificate or degree programs. These courses are a perfect fit for JCC's Hospitality & Tourism AAS & Applied Business Studies AOS degree programs.
005d95b1-bb37-4b23-b172-4b098e1e0a25.name: Hospitality Microcredential

badge_template_activities.title: HOS 101, Intro to Hospitality - 3 credits. This course provides a basic understanding of the lodging, foodservice, travel and tourism industry by tracing industry growth and development, reviewing the organization of business operations, and by focusing on industry opportunities and future trends.

HRM 274, Bartending Management - 3 credits. This course presents a systematic approach to bartending procedures by detailing the flow of beverage business through a bar beginning with mixology and ending with cash settlement. The principal objective of this course is to teach students how to master the art of bartending. Students will be trained to prepare the wide variety of drinks on the market today.

CUL 130, Sanitation and Safety - 1 credit. The course examines the proper sanitation and safety methods in the food service industry. Emphasis will be placed on problems, procedures, techniques, and practices in sanitation and safety. This course includes the exam for a sanitation certificate, accredited by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) -Conference for Food Protection (CFP).

BUS 230, Customer Service - 3 credits. This course provides students with an overview of basic concepts & current trends in the customer service industry. Emphasis placed on developing an organizational customer service philosophy as well as consistency & quality in customer service delivery. Special areas of study include problem solving, development of a customer service strategy, creation of customer service systems, handling challenging customers, customer retention & measuring satisfaction.
CPE professional development series.

4304131c-d221-4183-84be-abdf9645749b.description: The Kitchen Basics microcredential will provide those looking to start their career in the culinary industry with the background to work in food service, while learning necessary skills such as basic culinary, sanitation and safety, and beverage management. Students will earn 9 college credit hours that may later be transferred to one of Jefferson's certificate or degree programs. These courses are a perfect fit for JCC's Hospitality & Tourism AAS & Applied Business Studies AOS degree programs.
4304131c-d221-4183-84be-abdf9645749b.name: Kitchen Basics Microcredential

badge_template_activities.title: CUL 130, Sanitation & Safety - 1 credit. The course examines the proper sanitation and safety methods in the food service industry. Emphasis will be placed on problems, procedures, techniques, and practices in sanitation and safety. This course includes the exam for a sanitation certificate, accredited by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) -Conference for Food Protection (CFP).

CUL 102, Intro to Culinary - 2 credits. Designed to provide a foundation for development of culinary theory and practical skills needed by both culinary arts students and hotel/restaurant management students. Topics covered include sanitation and safety techniques, nutrition planning and awareness, basic skill development, product identification, and proper cooking methods for various types of foods. Students will be introduced to and will prepare mother and minor sauces, stocks, and soups.

CUL 120, Nutrition - 3 credits. This course will provide students with the nutritional knowledge required to develop and modify recipes and menus to meet the needs of an increasingly health conscious public. Students will develop a practical systems approach to deliver nutritional alternatives to food service customers.

HRM 240, Food & Beverage Management - 3 credits. This course provides a basic understanding of the principles of food and beverage production and service management. The course covers effective layout and design, sanitation and safety, menu planning, the purchasing cycle, and cost control procedures for both products and payroll.

6308c019-6965-4d3d-9a69-482b88f1d6de.description: The New Faculty and Staff series is designed to welcome new hires to the campus and introduce them to the culture of Jefferson using the FISH! Philosophy. FISH! relies on four basic principles - Be There, Play, Make Their Day, and Choose Your Attitude. At this session, new hires were welcomed to the series, including an introduction to the CPE, Jefferson, the mission for this series and each other.
6308c019-6965-4d3d-9a69-482b88f1d6de.name: New Faculty and Staff Series - Welcome and Introduction

badge_template_activities.title: This badge shows that participants have attended the New Faculty and Staff Series at the Center for Professional Excellence. By attending this event, recipients have demonstrated an interest in professional development..The New Faculty and Staff series is designed to welcome new hires to the campus and introduce them to the culture of Jefferson using the FISH! Philosophy.  FISH! relies on four basic principles - Be There, Play, Make Their Day, and Choose Your Attitude.

a0b84cd4-e64c-413a-86be-7476f3671efc.description: This microcredential prepares students to demonstrate competency in leadership characteristics; demonstrate an understanding of non-profit culture, organizational goals, and strategies. Students will gain an understanding of best practices for exceptional leadership & knowledge to establish strategies for success. Students will earn 9college credits that may later be transferred to a certificate or degree program. These courses are a perfect fit for JCC's Applied Business Studies degree program.
a0b84cd4-e64c-413a-86be-7476f3671efc.name: Non-Profit Leadership Microcredential

badge_template_activities.title: BUS 121: Business Financial Operations - 3 credits. This course provides an overview of the financial aspects of running a business. Topics include the basics of finance and economic concepts; financial management and planning, financial statements, profit, profitability, and break-even analysis; forecasting; managing working capital; budgeting, and finance.

BUS 131: Principles of Management - 3 credits. This course introduces students to skills and techniques used by management to achieve objectives. Included are: nature of management; qualifications of a manager; theories, mechanics, and dynamics of organizations; and planning, controlling, staffing, and coordinating.

BUS 216: Non-Profit Management - 3 credits. Designed to enhance understanding of nonprofit organizations & their role in the community. Topics include an overview of nonprofit structure, volunteerism, community responsibility, grant writing, nonprofit law, nonprofit finances, & board member responsibilities. Ethics will be embedded in the course. Area nonprofit organizations will be discussed in the course, & grants will be studied to increase critical thinking & problem-solving skills.

57f9c04b-faff-47e9-a0dc-874487dcdfce.description: Students in this course learn how to be successful pharmacy technicians by learning about effective communication strategies, laws, regulations and ethical concepts related to pharmacy practice, pharmacology terminology and abbreviations, inventory management, health insurance billing, dosage calculations, routes of administrations, drug classifications and examples, anatomy, physiology and common diseases for each body system, and the drugs in the current Top 200 Drug List.
57f9c04b-faff-47e9-a0dc-874487dcdfce.name: Pharmacy Technician Pre-Certification Program

badge_template_activities.title: Students must attend class and participate in discussions and labs.
Students must take and pass three quizzes and one final exam incorporating all topics covered during the course.
Students participate in a practical application to understand how to count medications, blister pack, and make an IV using aseptic technique.

5ab126d9-aa2c-40c7-afdc-295e50359918.description: Professional Development Day is a day-long event comprised of a keynote address and various break-out sessions. Through breakout sessions this earner is able to better understand fiscal planning, leadership, personal well-being, professional skill development, managing change and changes in higher education, and utilizing technology to engage students.
5ab126d9-aa2c-40c7-afdc-295e50359918.name: Professional Development Day 2020

badge_template_activities.title: Attend the all-day event.

7efdf03e-cbbc-4541-a386-bb8dd5ab77d8.description: Professional Development Day is a day-long event comprised of a keynote address and various break-out sessions. This year's keynote speaker was Dr. Tia Brown McNair. Through breakout sessions this earner is able to better understand fiscal planning, leadership, personal well-being, professional skill development, managing change and changes in higher education, and utilizing technology to engage students.
7efdf03e-cbbc-4541-a386-bb8dd5ab77d8.name: Professional Development Day Fall 2021

badge_template_activities.title: Attend the all-day event.

af33dbe7-cec3-4094-a62d-deb87a117b56.description: Professional Development Day is a day-long event comprised of a keynote address and various break-out sessions. This year's theme was Reflect, Rejuvenate, Renew with keynote speaker Jeff Yalden. Through breakout sessions this earner is able to better understand fiscal planning, leadership, personal well-being, professional skill development, managing change and changes in higher education, and utilizing technology to engage students.
af33dbe7-cec3-4094-a62d-deb87a117b56.name: Professional Development Day Fall 2022

badge_template_activities.title: Attend the all-day event.

03ef311d-a37b-42b5-9274-169653c15cdb.description: Students will learn to create accurate & complete top-down designs, algorithms, & programs w/functions and/or objects in computer programming languages currently used in industry & to use data modeling methods. Students will earn 10 credits that may be transferred to a certificate or degree program. These courses are a perfect fit for JCC's Computer Science A.S., Computer Information Systems A.S., Computer Information Technology A.A.S., Engineering Science A.S., and Mathematics A.S. degrees.
03ef311d-a37b-42b5-9274-169653c15cdb.name: Software Development Microcredential

badge_template_activities.title: CIS 116, Introductory Programming - 3 credits. This is an introductory course designed to familiarize the student with the use of a structured programming language and the microcomputer system. A structured approach to problem solving and the development of algorithms will be presented and applied to the writing of computer programs. This course is designed for those with little or no experience with computer programming.

CIS 216, Advanced Programming - 4 credits. This course is designed to use a modern programming language in the solution of advanced problems in the areas of business and science. Topics include recursion, data structures, file organization and processing, structures and numerical methods.

CIS 250, Data Structures - 3 credits. This course is a further study of topics in program and algorithm development. Topics include structured and object-oriented programming concepts, arrays, structures, string processing, stacks, queues, linked lists, pointer variables, recursion, and internal searching and sorting methods.
